newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Low peso demand keeps Philippine call money steady.
newsitem.headline: Low peso demand keeps Philippine call money steady.

text.p: The Philippine interbank call loan rate remained rooted at 10.53125 percent as demand for overnight money eased, traders said.
Turnover in the market dwindled to 5.665 billion pesos from Monday's 9.112 billion pesos.
"There are no borrowers, but there were a lot of lenders," one trader said. Most of the banks with excess funds were lending to the Central Bank at 10.5 percent.
Other banks were investing in reverse repos which remained high despite the slipping Treasury bill rates.
Some banks were also preparing for the 10-year Treasury bond auction to be held next Tuesday. The auction committee has increased the volume to 5.0 billion pesos from 2.0 billion pesos.
The secondary government securities market was active but rates remained flat.
"Banks are not taking positions since they believe rates will correct in the coming weeks. Most of the buyers are just selling them to their clients," another trader said.
Three-month bills were being bid between 10.725 and 10.85 percent, while being offered between 10.60 and 10.70 percent.
Six-month bills were being bought between 10.95 and 11.15 percent, while sold between 10.90 to 11.05 percent.
One-year bills were being bid between 11.425 and 11.50 percent, and offered between 11.35 to 11.40 percent.
